content.formatted_body:
Hey all... had some feedback come up with regards to Explicit Resource Management today that I wanted to surface and get some input on. The question specifically is, "I think explicit resource management is missing a really important feature: The ability to transfer ownership. I need a way to "release" a variable I declared with using, especially to return it." ... essentially treating the ERM/using as similar to an RAII that can be moved away.

function foo() {
  using foo = new Foo();
  using bar = new Bar();
  // I only want foo or bar disposed if they are not returned
  if (someCondition()) return bar; 
  else return foo;
}

content.body: Unfortunately, since both are declared with `using`, both are going to be disposed when the function returns. The ask from the feedback is whether it would make sense to have some generalized "release" or "move" capability.. like `return move bar`, etc
content.formatted_body: Unfortunately, since both are declared with using, both are going to be disposed when the function returns. The ask from the feedback is whether it would make sense to have some generalized "release" or "move" capability.. like return move bar, etc

content.body: obviously we can follow a pattern similar to `DisposableStack` and have the disposable object itself declare a `move()` method but that means allocating a new object or having to keep track of the moved state manually
content.formatted_body: obviously we can follow a pattern similar to DisposableStack and have the disposable object itself declare a move() method but that means allocating a new object or having to keep track of the moved state manually

content.body: So I think one of the good things about explicit resource management is its simplicity, there isn't much of an ownership or lifetime model to think about or to get wrong.
we can also null/undefined out the original decl and assign it to a regular scoped variable but that's also a bit wonky
100% agree
I think I'd prefer seeing people declaring `move()` themselves rather than trying to design something in the language.
content.formatted_body: I think I'd prefer seeing people declaring move() themselves rather than trying to design something in the language.

content.body: But now I'm curious if typescript could layer a full borrow checker on top and do this automatically. :-)
* we can also null/undefined out the original decl and assign it to a regular scoped variable but that's also a bit wonky .... actually, nevermind, I don't think this works

m.new_content.body: we can also null/undefined out the original decl and assign it to a regular scoped variable but that's also a bit wonky .... actually, nevermind, I don't think this works

content.body: Making every disposable object declare a `move()` is a bit ... difficult.  From the conversation I'm having in another channel on this, "It has to allocate a new instance of itself and move all the contents over to it. This is a lot of work to write for every type. And if anything else in the world holds a (presumably non-owning) reference to the object, those references are now invalid, so it might not even be possible to implement move() correctly, at least without adding a layer of indirection."
content.formatted_body: Making every disposable object declare a move() is a bit ... difficult. From the conversation I'm having in another channel on this, "It has to allocate a new instance of itself and move all the contents over to it. This is a lot of work to write for every type. And if anything else in the world holds a (presumably non-owning) reference to the object, those references are now invalid, so it might not even be possible to implement move() correctly, at least without adding a layer of indirection."

content.body: I think I need to sleep on it. I've started writing an reply about 5 times, and deleted them 5 times. My essential concern is that both the 'other non-owning references becoming invalid' and the return of the resource suggest that it is leaking in ways that probably aren't good for an explicit allocated and released resource (the former because we seem to have lost ownership during the method's lifetime, and the latter because we can't require the result is allocated to a variable declared with `using`).
content.formatted_body: I think I need to sleep on it. I've started writing an reply about 5 times, and deleted them 5 times. My essential concern is that both the 'other non-owning references becoming invalid' and the return of the resource suggest that it is leaking in ways that probably aren't good for an explicit allocated and released resource (the former because we seem to have lost ownership during the method's lifetime, and the latter because we can't require the result is allocated to a variable declared with using).

content.body: yeah, it's a tricky one

I prefer the simplicity of ERM as it is but compared to the typical RAII pattern in c++, etc it's a bit *over* simplified... and that's there the questions here are coming from. We have a code base that is quite heavy in RAII mechanisms and the c++ level with no equivalent at the JS level
content.formatted_body: I prefer the simplicity of ERM as it is but compared to the typical RAII pattern in c++, etc it's a bit over simplified... and that's there the questions here are coming from. We have a code base that is quite heavy in RAII mechanisms and the c++ level with no equivalent at the JS level

content.body: If we get Symbol.enter/exit, then you'd be able to declare a function `movable` that you'd use as `using x = movable(foo)`

content.formatted_body:
Another example to stew on...

function foo() {
  using bar = new MyDisposable();
  if (someCondition()) throw new Error('boom'); // I want bar disposed in this case
  return bar;  // I don't want it disposed in this case
}

content.body: Is there an open proposal for this?
and is it functions only?

Actually maybe you don't need .enter? (Sorry my element client is refusing to format markdown)

Instead of
```
using foo = getObj()
```
you can do
```
const foo = getObj();
using move = movable(foo)

...

move()
```

Where movable returns a function move that returns foo and has its own dispose method, deactivated by move.

* Actually maybe you don't need .enter? (Sorry my element client is refusing to format markdown)

Instead of
```
using foo = getObj()
```
you can do
```
const foo = getObj();
using move = movable(foo)

...

move()
```

Where movable returns a function move that returns foo and has its own dispose method forwarded to foo, deactivated by move.

content.formatted_body:
function movable(foo) {
  let dispose = foo[Symbol.dispose];
  if (typeof dispose !== 'function') throw new Error('not disposable');
  return {
    resource: foo,
    moved: false,
    [Symbol.dispose]() {
      if (this.moved) return;
      dispose.call(foo);
    },
    move() {
      this.moved = true;
    },
  }
}

// usage:
function makeDisposable() {
  return {
    [Symbol.dispose]() {
      console.log('disposed');
    },
  };
}
{
  using movableFoo = movable(makeDisposable());
  const { resource: foo } = movableFoo;
  console.log('normal exit');
  // disposed
}
{
  using movableFoo = movable(makeDisposable());
  const { resource: foo } = movableFoo;
  movableFoo.move();
  console.log('moved before exit');
  // not disposed
}

content.body: this seems like it's fine to leave to userland
it's a little boilerplate I guess
Could make .move return a new movable in the same way DisposableStack.p.move returns a new Stack
content.formatted_body: Could make .move return a new movable in the same way DisposableStack.p.move returns a new Stack

content.formatted_body: or maybe just return the resource after nulling it out

m.new_content.formatted_body:
function movable(foo) {
  let dispose = foo[Symbol.dispose];
  if (typeof dispose !== 'function') throw new Error('not disposable');
  return {
    resource: foo,
    moved: false,
    [Symbol.dispose]() {
      if (this.moved) return;
      dispose.call(foo);
    },
    move() {
      this.moved = true;
      return foo;
    },
  }
}

content.body: I think just returning the resource is better for the cases described above; presumably the caller is not expecting this wrapped thing and _a priori_ there is no reason to expect them to want to move it again
content.formatted_body: I think just returning the resource is better for the cases described above; presumably the caller is not expecting this wrapped thing and a priori there is no reason to expect them to want to move it again
